For questions, contact: Alex Nedzel, 617-461-7823

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP.  Your safety, and the safety of the group, is the most important thing. If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk – consider this before you decide to register.

In addition to showing your interest here on Meetup, you need to register at https://hbbostonamc.org/regi/326.  If you haven't used the AMC Boston Chapter registration system before, you'll first be asked to take a couple of minutes to create a brief, reusable registration profile for yourself.  When registering for this trip on the AMC system, be sure to answer all questions. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

=====

What we're doing

Join us for an ambitious bushwhack of Mts. Deception (3671') and Dartmouth (3727'), two NH Hundred Highest peaks that share a long ridge. Expect an early start and a full day of dense, challenging bushwhacking.  We will be treated to innumerable breathtaking, close-up views of spruce and fir boughs as we push around and/or through them. We will also have the opportunity to test our agility and guile at navigating around and through various bogs and blow-down swaths. Up to 6 miles of bushwhacking at a moderate pace, with 2000'-3000' of elevation gain. A major opportunity to exercise and hone your navigation and route finding skills.  Strenous.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

Guests are not permitted - all participants must register individually.

Dogs are not permitted on this hike.

=====

Weather

Mountain weather is subject to rapid changes and extreme conditions. Dangerous weather conditions will cancel - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants a day or two ahead of time. We will assess travel and weather conditions during the hike and make changes to our planned trip as necessary.

  • Click for the current weather forecast (noaa.gov)

=====

Clothing, Gear, Equipment, and Supplies

Hiking safely is about being prepared so that you can respond to an emergency situation or spend a night in the woods if you have to. Failure to bring the basics puts you and the rest of the group at risk. The basics include:

  • Footwear: Hiking Boots. Synthetic or wool socks. Gaiters are optional.
  • Clothing: Dress in synthetic or wool layers to easily regulate body temperature. DO NOT WEAR COTTON - it doesn't insulate if it gets wet and it is difficult to dry.
  • Outerwear: Windproof/waterproof shell (with hood) and pants. Sunglasses. You should still bring a fleece/wool hat and a pair of gloves.
  • Gear: Map & Compass - don't just bring them but know how to use them. Plastic whistle. Headlamp with two sets of spare batteries. Small pocket knife or multi-purpose tool. Trekking poles. Camera.
  • Emergency Shelter: Be prepared to spend a night in the woods if you have to. Options include an ultralight tarp, a bivy sack, or an emergency space blanket.
  • Supplies: Enough water to stay hydrated. Enough food to stay nourished. Toilet kit (e.g. hand sanitizer, toilet paper, and a zip-lock bag to pack out your used personal hygiene items). Personal First-Aid Kit with any medications that you might need. Sunscreen. Lip balm. Matches or a wind-proof lighter and some fire starter.

Since we will be bushwhacking, we recommend you leave your best clothes at home. You should also bring a pair of safety glasses/goggles that you can wear to protect your eyes.

If you don't know what to wear and/or bring with you or have any questions either refer to the list below or contact me.

  • Click for a list of required items needed for a day hike (Appalachian Mountain Club)

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip.

If you don't have what you need you will not be allowed to participate - even if you carpooled with someone.

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Once your registration is approved on the AMC system, you will see the contact info and geographic info for all participants.  If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses - suggested donations per person are $20 from Boston MA, $15 from Salem/Nashua NH, and $10 from Concord NH.

=====
